titlestmt.titleproper: Chandler, Alfred D., 1918-2007. Papers, 1941-2004: A Finding Aid

titlepage.titleproper: Chandler, Alfred D. (Alfred Dupont), 1918-2007. Papers, 1940-2007: A Finding Aid
titlepage.author: Baker Library

physdesc.extent: 125 linear ft. (284 boxes, 1 carton, 4 oversize boxes, 3 volumes, and 3 oversize folders)

did.abstract: The collection includes papers of Professor Alfred D. Chandler documenting his research, teaching, and other professional activities.

processinfo.p: Processed: 1993; revised 2004 by Katherine Powers; additions processed 2010 by April Johnson.

acqinfo.head: Provenance:
acqinfo.p: Gift of Alfred D. Chandler. The collection was received in separate accessions between 1989-2010.

Material related to General Motors was donated by Alfred D. Chandler in 1971. These papers were previously cataloged with the Baker Library Historical Collections Manuscripts Collection (MSS: 534 1908-1960). They consist of interviews, memos, drafts, and other records related to the publication of Alfred P. Sloan's book My Years with General Motors.

accessrestrict.p: Restricted material has been indentified and separated. Note that box and folder lists of restricted material have been redacted. See Archivist for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: Alfred D. Chandler Papers. HBS Archives. Baker Library Historical Collections. Harvard Business School.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material:
relatedmaterial.p: Papers of Fay Chandler, 1934-2004. Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note:
bioghist.p: Alfred Dupont Chandler was born in Guyencourt, Delaware on September 15, 1918. He received his BA in history from Harvard College in 1940 and attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill from 1945 to 1946 (from which he received an MA in history in 1951). He returned to Harvard in 1946 and received his MA in 1947 and then PhD in 1952, both in history. He married Fay Martin in 1944 and had four children.

Chandler wrote his dissertation on Henry Varnum Poor, his great-grandfather, whose personal papers he discovered stored in the house of a deceased aunt. His dissertation eventually became his first book, Henry Varnum Poor, Business Editor, Analyst and Reformer, published in 1956. It was through studying Poor’s comparative analysis of railroads, the first U.S. large-scale enterprise, that Chandler began his career-long engagement with the study of change in business structure and managerial organization. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1940-1945 as Lt. Commander, which gave him valuable, first-hand experience with a giant enterprise.

Chandler was a research associate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1950-1951 and taught there from 1951-1963. In 1954 he served as academic consultant at the Naval War College, where he conceived the idea for Strategy and Structure, his second book, which was published in 1962, and won the Newcomen Award. During his time at MIT he also wrote a number of articles, served as assistant editor of four volumes of The Letters of Theodore Roosevelt, and was consulting historical advisor to Alfred P. Sloan Jr. in the writing of Sloan’s My Years with General Motors, published in 1964.

Chandler taught at Johns Hopkins University from 1963-1970, serving as chairman of the history department for four years and as director of the Center for the Study of Recent History for three years. He edited and compiled Giant Enterprise: Ford, General Motors, and the Automobile Industry, published in 1964, and The Railroads, The Nation’s First Big Business, published in 1965. He also co-edited The Changing Economic Order: Readings in American Business and Economic History, published in 1968, and edited and co-edited six volumes of The Papers of Dwight D. Eisenhower.

During his years at HBS, Chandler traveled extensively around the United States, Europe and Japan for conferences and lectures. In addition he was visiting fellow at All Souls College, Oxford (1975), visiting professor at the European Institute of Advanced Studies in Management, Brussels (1979), and Walker-Ames Visiting Professor at the University of Washington (1981).

Throughout his career, Chandler was actively engaged with numerous professional organizations and conferences, often in leadership roles. Among them were the Economic History Association, the Society for the History of Technology, the American Historical Association, the Organization of American Historians, the Massachusetts Historical Society, the Business History Conference, the Eleutherian Mills Hagley Foundation, the American Philosophical Society, the Business History Foundation, and the Council on Research in Economic History. He was chairman of the Advisory History Committee of the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission (the AEC was dismantled in 1975 and superseded by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Energy Research and Development Administration) and also served on advisory boards and committees for the corporate histories of business corporations, among them, the British Petroleum Company, Alcoa, Citibank, and Du Pont’s Research and Development Division.

Alfred Chandler received honorary degrees from the University of Leuven, Belgium (1976), the University of Antwerp, Belgium (1979), Italian Academy of Business Economy (1980), Babson College, Massachusetts (1982), Ohio State University (1987), York University, Canada (1988), New England College (1992), University of Delaware (2002), and Northeastern University (2002). In 1995 he was awarded the Distinguished Service Award which is Harvard's highest honor.
Alfred Chandler died on May 9, 2007 in Cambridge, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note:
scopecontent.p: The collection reflects the work and intellectual development of Alfred D. Chandler from graduate school at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Harvard University, through his tenures at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Johns Hopkins University, and Harvard Business School, to his position as professor emeritus. The collection covers a period of over sixty years during which Chandler studied the historical evolution and organizational development of the modern corporation.

The collection includes many of his lecture and seminar notes and almost the entire body of his professional correspondence. The collection documents his and others’ research on and interpretation of the evolution of the modern corporation; his editorial work on the papers of Theodore Roosevelt and Dwight D. Eisenhower; his role as trustee and president of the Economic History Association and as executive board member of the Organization of American Historians; and his involvement with many other professional and scholarly organizations, especially in contributing to business history conferences, editing papers, and overseeing their publication. The collection includes manuscript versions of his and others’ work. It is also rich in research material gathered in the course of his comparative studies of corporate structure and its development in the United States and in other industrial economies, including a wealth of research notes taken and photocopies made from records in institutional and company archives.

The collection is divided into eleven series. The first five represent stages in Chandler’s career and institutional affiliation; the sixth consists of audio-visual material; the seventh of restricted Harvard University and Harvard Business School administration records; the eighth of restricted Harvard University and Harvard Business School student and personnel records; the ninth of biographical materials; the tenth of ephemera; and the final of offprints of publications by Alfred Chandler. Contents of both restricted series were separated according to Harvard University guidelines.

processinfo.head: Processing note:
processinfo.p: The arrangement of the collection follows as closely as possible the original order of the material as they were arranged by Alfred D. Chandler, though that order was not always systematic. Chandler often created groups of records that were neither alphabetically nor chronologically arranged, and over the years he extracted material from earlier projects for use or refinement in current ones. This order does, in fact, reflect the way in which Chandler shaped his conclusions and reveals the bearing that his previous work and the work of others had on the development of his ideas. As a consequence, these groups have been left intact.

scopecontent.p: This series documents Alfred Chandler's early educational and professional work and includes materials that reflect Chandler’s service in the U.S. Military, his work as a graduate student at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill (MA 1951), and undergraduate and graduate work at Harvard University (BA 1940, MA 1947, PhD 1952). Types of materials include course work, military records, notes, exams and papers. The series is organized into three subseries: A. Military Records, B. University of North Carolina, and C. Harvard University.

This subseries consists of material kept by Alfred Chandler while serving in the U.S. Navy and includes his Officer Service Record, documentation of his release from active duty, commendation, veteran's benefit materials, and photographs.

Series II. Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Johns Hopkins University, 1949-1978

scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers related to Alfred Chandler’s teaching, research, and writing activities while a faculty member at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (1950-1963) and Johns Hopkins University (1963-1970). Material related to MIT includes correspondence and subject files, research and writings, including Chandler’s contribution to Alfred P. Sloan’s autobiography, MIT teaching and administrative records, and conferences and professional memberships.Material related to Johns Hopkins University includes correspondence and subject files, research and writings, teaching and administrative records, and conferences and professional memberships.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. MIT Correspondence and Subject Files, 1951-1965

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of Alfred Chandler's correspondence and subject files kept while teaching at MIT where he taught from 1950-1963. The correspondents include Chandler's colleagues, students, fellow scholars, business executives, family, and friends. The subjects covered include: Chandler's graduate degree; grants; the research of others; Chandler's work, in particular his biographies of Henry Varnum Poor and Pierre S. du Pont; his research on Standard Oil, General Motors, and the DuPont Company; invitations to apply for teaching positions, to present papers, and to write reviews; and Chandler family matters. Of particular interest are Chandler's communications with Professor Howard R. Bartlett which list his accomplishments and summarize his research projects and objectives. Correspondence can also be found in each of the other series.

Subseries B. MIT Research and Writing, 1949-1967

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of research and writing projects undertaken by Alfred Chandler during his tenure at MIT and includes research on Theodore Roosevelt which was used for the publication of Letters of Theodore Roosevelt, including drafts of essays on Roosevelt and the Progressive Party. This series also includes research for Henry Varnum Poor, Business Editor, Analyst, and Reformer (1956), which consists of correspondence, 1963-1978, photocopies of the American Railroad Journal, 1831-1859, original pamphlets from railroads, photographs and negatives, and Chandler's doctoral thesis entitled, "The Pen in Business: A Biography of Henry Varnum Poor," that was presented to the History Department at Harvard University in August 1951.

Another area of research in this subseries includes the study of business bureaucracies which was a precursor to Strategy and Structure (1962). These records consist of drafts, reading notes, and research notes on various companies. Research related to the publication of Strategy and Structure, consists of correspondence, drafts, reading notes, research notes, and material on companies, in particular the DuPont Company (which includes transcripts and notes from company files, 1917-1921) and Standard Oil of New Jersey (which includes transcripts and notes from company files including the Clark Papers, 1923-1933, Lee and Sadler Papers, 1917-1929, and circular letters, 1921-1934).

There is a second group of Standard Oil of New Jersey records which, though used for Strategy and Structure, was deposited separately. It consists of photocopies, transcripts, and notes from the Clark Papers, 1917-1933, circular letters, 1923-1929, the Sadler Papers, 1924, and the Lee Papers, 1922-1927 (much of this duplicates the earlier deposited material), and notes from interviews of company officials.

This subseries also includes research on railroads which consists of material used for a deleted Strategy and Structure chapter and later used for the book The Visible Hand (1977). It includes notes and photocopies from the Burlington Line Company, 1873-1888; notes and transcripts from the Illinois Central Line, 1884-1889; and a draft of the railroad chapter deleted from Strategy and Structure. Also included in this subseries is research materials related to Major Crises in American History (1962) edited by Merrill D. Peterson and Leonard W. Levy, a two-volume work with which Chandler contributed two chapters. The material consists of correspondence, drafts, and notes. This subseries also includes material related to the publication of Giant Enterprise (1964), which consists of correspondence, drafts, notes, and text material.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by date of publication.

Subseries C. MIT Research and Writing: Alfred P. Sloan Autobiography - General Motors, 1954-1960

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of Alfred Chandler’s correspondence and research materials relating to the writing of Alfred P. Sloan’s My Years with General Motors (1964). Chandler was consulting historian and research associate to Sloan from 1956 to 1960. He regularly corresponded with Sloan and his editors, John McDonald and Catharine Stevens. The research materials include Chandler’s notes, copies of General Motors' correspondence, reports, legal papers, published documents, and transcriptions of interviews. It also includes rough drafts of several chapters from the book.

arrangement.p: The material in this subseries is in the original order.

acqinfo.p: This subseries was donated by Alfred Chandler in 1971 and was previously cataloged with the Baker Library Historical Collections Manuscripts Collection (Manuscript call number MSS: 534 1908-1960).

Subseries J. Johns Hopkins University Research and Writing, 1958-1972

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of research and writing projects undertaken by Alfred Chandler during his time at Johns Hopkins University. This subseries includes records of the DuPont Project (published in 1971 as Pierre S. du Pont and the Making of the Modern Corporation) which includes transcripts and notes from the DuPont Company's Executive Committee minutes, 1903-1910, and from the Raskob Papers, 1914-1925, as well as transcripts and notes from Chandler's interviews of men who were DuPont Company executives in the early twentieth century. In addition, it includes correspondence, drafts, and research notes.

This subseries also includes material related to "The Role of the Firm" (published in 1964 as "La role de la firm dans l'economie americaine"), "The Structure of American Industry" (1969), and the "Eisenhower Project," which consists chiefly of material relating to Chandler's talk, "Dwight D. Eisenhower: The Training and the Tasks" (given in 1966). Materials include correspondence, research notes, and photocopies of primary and secondary sources, reprints, drafts of manuscripts, financial information, and clippings.

arrangement.p: Research projects are arranged chronologically by date of publication. The material within the projects has been left in its original order.

Series III. Harvard Business School (HBS), Active Tenure, 1968-1991

scopecontent.p: This series consists of records created and collected by Alfred Chandler during his active tenure at HBS as Isidor Straus Professor of Business History (1970–1989) and during his transition to Professor Emeritus (1989-1991). This series includes correspondence and subject files, research and writings (including research related to The Visible Hand and Scale and Scope), and materials related to teaching, attending conferences, and professional memberships.

arrangement.p: The series occasionally includes records created at an earlier or later period because they were inter-filed by Chandler.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. HBS Correspondence and Subject Files, Active Tenure, 1968-1988

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the material in this subseries falls between 1970 and 1987. Some correspondence is dated well before Alfred Chandler's tenure at HBS. These early letters include correspondence with Arthur Cole, economic historian and Harvard Business School librarian, from 1962, which has been retained here to preserve the original order. This subseries consists of letters to Chandler and copies of letters from him. Accompanying the correspondence are photocopied articles, reprints, and manuscripts. The topics covered in this series include appraisal of his work by others (often including annotated manuscripts), exchanges of views and information on aspects of business history, requests for reviews, invitations to speak, permissions, and travel arrangements.

processinfo.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent and subject title.

accessrestrict.p: Correspondence relating to Alfred Chandler's appointment to the Isidor Straus Chair at HBS and his reports on his research activities and plans to the Division of Research and Faculty Development and to the Dean of Harvard Business School have been separated and placed in the fifty-year restricted Administration and Program records.

Subseries C. HBS Research and Writing, General, 1970-1988

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of research and writing projects undertaken by Alfred Chandler during his time as a professor at HBS. The material includes research notes, photocopies of primary and secondary research material, newspaper clippings, corrected drafts, and correspondence concerning the works, including comments from others who read Chandler's manuscripts.

This subseries includes material related to The Visible Hand which was published in 1977 (additional material related to The Visible Hand can also be found in Series II); and materials related to Scale and Scope: the Dynamics of Industrial Capitalism which was published in 1990. The latter includes photocopied records on many business firms, including material from the library of Imperial Chemicals, Ltd., London, 1919-1968, consisting of memos, letters, minutes, reports, addresses, and charts detailing the organization and method of operation.

Also included are records from Boots, Ltd., 1920-1978, including minutes and reports; materials from Unilever, 1922-1939, including minutes and Alfred Chandler's notes; material from the Siemens archives; and material on General Electric and Allegemeine Elektricitaets Gesellscaff from the Owen D. Young Papers, 1926-1930. Owen D. Young was the president of General Electric.

processinfo.p: Research material and articles not associated with a specific project have been placed at the end. Beyond that, the material has been left in its original order within the project groups and file folders.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by project and date of publication. The date of creation sometimes predates Chandler's tenure at HBS. There is some undated material, which has been placed at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials kept Alfred Chandler documenting his teaching activities at Harvard Business School. Seminars and courses include: “The Evolution of American Business Enterprise (1970)”, “The History of Large-Scale Business Enterprise”, “The Rise of Managerial Capitalism: The World”, “The Coming of Managerial Capitalism: The World”, “The Development of the Modern Corporation in International Perspective”, “Competition and Industry Structure”, “Technology, Competition and Industry Structure”, “Innovation, Public Policy, and Industrial Structure”, “Business in its Historical Environment”, and “The Coming of Managerial Capitalism: The U.S.”

The material consists of lecture notes, class outlines, syllabi, reading lists, exam questions, transparencies, photocopied and reprinted class material, and photocopies of Chandler's works-in-progress used for classes. These are frequently annotated. This subseries also includes a group of cases, 1972-1983 written by others but annotated by Chandler; and cases written by Chandler including notes, drafts, and revisions.

Series IV. Harvard Business School, Emeritus, 1973-2007

scopecontent.p: This series documents Alfred Chandler's active work as Professor Emeritus at Harvard Business School. The series include correspondence and subject files, research and writings, and materials related to conferences, memberships, and talks.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. HBS Emeritus Correspondence and Subject Files 1973-2007

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of correspondence and subject files kept by Alfred Chandler related to research and writing, other people’s work, and conferences. There are also papers written by others, film scripts for TV productions, and photocopied articles. The bulk of the material was created between 1991 and 2007, although there are files from earlier years, which were brought forward and kept active by Chandler. The files are, in general, arranged alphabetically, though there are chronologically arranged files for 1992 that include both Alfred Chandler’s and his correspondents’ letters. There are also chronological files for 1993 to 1995, which consist only of Chandler’s photocopied outgoing letters, chronological correspondence for 1995-2007, and emails for 2002-2006.

Subseries B. HBS Emeritus Research and Writings, 1988-2005

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of material related to research and writing projects undertaken by Alfred Chandler while Professor Emeritus at HBS including, Inventing the Electronic Century: The Epic Story of the Consumer Electronics and Computer Industries (2001) and Shaping the Industrial Century: The Remarkable Story of the Evolution of the Modern Chemical and Pharmaceutical Industries (2005). The research material includes notes, photocopies of primary and secondary research material, newspaper clippings, corrected drafts, and correspondence concerning the works, including comments from others who have read Chandler's manuscripts. Also includes some materials related to the publications Business History Around the World (2003), Leviathans (2005), and other academic papers and articles.

processinfo.p: The material has been left in its original order within the project groups and file folders.

arrangement.p: Primarily arranged chronologically by date of publication.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of audio-visual materials kept by Alfred Chandler and includes photographs, videos, and Dictabelt recordings. Photographs consist of personal photographs as well as photographs taken at various events. Video recordings are of Chandler being interviewed and at the Harvard commencement. The Dictabelts include recordings of Alfred Chandler dictating research notes and commentaries on student work while at MIT and Johns Hopkins University.
. This subseries contains photographs of Alfred Chandler and family, his professional and academic colleagues and professional events. Many of the photographs were removed from correspondence files.

Includes dictated notes related to research on DuPont, General Motors and Standard Oil. The recordings were made around 1965. Some of the transcriptions of the recordings can be found throughout the collection (primarily with MIT and Johns Hopkins University related material) as typescripts filed with research notes.

processinfo.p: These files were found in the original collection arrangement as a discrete series of confidential records and have been maintained during the 2004 processing project as a distinct and restricted series.

accessrestrict.p: This subseries is restricted until 2065. See Archivist for information.
Note that folder titles have been redacted.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of biographical materials related to Alfred Chandler including clippings, press releases, autobiographical writings, awards, certificates, diplomas, and honorary degrees.

This subseries consists of biographical materials pertaining to Alfred Chandler’s personal life and career. The material consists of clippings, press releases, a family tree, autobiographical writings about Chandler’s early adult years, and materials related to his death in 2007.

Subseries B. Awards, certificates and degrees, 1947-2003

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of various awards, certificates and degrees that Alfred Chandler acquired over his nearly 60 years as a business historian. Some of the materials also include a small amount of correspondence and other related records. Of particular interest is Chandler’s Distinguished Service Award from Harvard University and related materials, 1995.

scopecontent.p: This series contains various ephemera and memorabilia collected by and presented to Alfred Chandler. Materials include medals, pins, a Japanese print and engraving and a ceremonial wand. Most of the materials are undated.

scopecontent.p: This series contains offprints of publications written by Alfred Chandler from 1949-2005. These offprints were kept on file by Alfred Chandler, most likely to distribute to researchers as requested.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically.
